info.title: Elasticsearch Basics
info.description:
This Swagger UI page runs throught the basic Elasticsearch API end points. It is intended to be used as a first introduction for anybody looking to pick upsome elasticsearch knowledge. 

The Swagger UI page runs through the basics of index management then runs through all the basic `CRUD` operations. Sample payloads and responses have been provided for each endpoint to assist in the learning processing. Every CRUD end point requires that you specify an index name as a path parameter.

For instructions on how to setup a elasticsearch cluster and connect up this Swagger UI page - head over to the [Swarmee Blog](https://www.swarmee.net/blog/2021-09-02-Elasticsearch-Basic-Training/).

get.description:
Retrieve Cluster Health 

Ideally your cluster is green (which means no unreplicated shards) 

Yellow means you have some unreplicated shards - if you create an index it may by default have mulitple shards.

`cat` stands for Compact and Aligned Text - there are many elasticserch endpoints under `_cat` 

These endpoints are meant for humans to read as the text is neatly aligned in columns. 

However they have evolved to have a format parameter so you can get `json` back from them also.

This `cat` endpoint list indices and provides their state 

The **v** parameter toggles the column headings on and off in the column view.

View the aliases, mappings and settings for an index.

_**Aliases**_ are similar to table views from sql land - i.e. they don't hold data - they just point to one or more indexes. 

_**Mappings**_ defines the type of each field and how it is indexes 

_**Settings**_ defines the index level configuration.

put.description:
Create an empty index in elasticsearch with a predefined configuration. 

Over time you will probably want to look at index templates - however you need to understand the fundamentals of index settings. 

Below are a number of index configurations.

simple_index_creation.description: A **simple** index configuration. In this example we are just setting the number of shards and replicas

complex_index_creation.summary: A more complex index settings configuration

basic_multifield_index_creation.description: This example highlights how one input field (name in this example) can be indexed multiple ways. What we have setup in this example is the name field being processed by three analyzers; the out of the box `standard` analyzer, and two custom analyzers. The first using the `keyword` and `lowercase` filters the second using the the `snowball` and `lowercase` filters.

delete.description:
Delete an index (and all documents contained within the index)

These types of endpoints support asterisk (`*`) as a wild. 

This is really helpful when you need to delete indices which have the date in the index name. E.g.; 

``` bash
curl -X 'DELETE' 'https://localhost/2020-01-*-applogs/' 
```
But be careful.

put.description:
Update an existing indexes settings. 

For example you might want to build an index with settings optimised for speed, however once its built you might want to optimise for redundancy (e.g. increasing the number of replicates), 

**Not** all index settings can be changed once an index is created.

update_index_setting.summary: A update to an index setting

post.description:
Inserting a document with an existing document _id will replace the existing document - So
if you need to replace a whole document with a existing document just use the create document 
with `_id` end point.
There are two types of updates `doc` and `script`:

- doc is used to add or update specific fields
- script is used to perform more complex updates (e.g. adding an item to an existing list)

update_document_new_field.summary: Add a field to a document
update_document_new_field.description: Add one additional field to a elasticsearch document

update_document_script_remove_field.summary: Remove a field from a document
update_document_script_remove_field.description: Remove a field from one elasticsearch document

update_document_add_list.summary: Add a list to a document
update_document_add_list.description: Add a list to an existing document

update_document_add_item_to_list_if_not_.summary: Add an item to a list if not already present
update_document_add_item_to_list_if_not_.description: Add an item to a list if not already present, note how the version number is not incremented and the result is `noop` when the value already exists in the list

script.source: /* first check to see if value is in the list */  if  (ctx._source.newList.contains(params.tag) != true) /* add it if not present */ {ctx._source.newList.add(params.tag)} else { ctx.op = 'none' }

post.description:
Delete all documents that match a query. All of the powerful search language can be used here
to identify what needs to be deleted. Depdending on the number of documents to be deleted you 
may choose to submit this request synchronously or asynchronously based on the `wait_for_completion`
flag. 

If you choose asynchronously you are provided a `task_id` that you can use to manage the request
at a later point.

update_document_by_query_add_new_field.summary: Add a field to documents that meet query
update_document_by_query_add_new_field.description: Add one additional field to all documents that meet the query

update_document_by_query_remove_new_fiel.summary: Remove a field from a document based on a query
update_document_by_query_remove_new_fiel.description: Remove one  field to all documents that meet the query

get.description:
This end point simply retrieves a document based on the provided `_id`. 

Note the structure of the document returned:
- At the top level we have various meta data about the document (e.g. `index` and `version`). 

- The original document is nested in a field called `_source`.

post.description:
Store a document into elasticsearch while specifying an `_id` for the record.

If the index to store the document does not already exist it will be created 
with the default settings and mapping parameters applied. 

If the index and `_id` already exist then the document will be replaced. 

Please see how the sample response differs (i.e. the `result` and `_version` fields)

simple_single_country1.description: A **simple** Afghanistan document with only a few fields

simple_single_country2.description: A **simple** √Öland Islands document with only a few fields

simple_single_country3.description: A **simple** American Samoa document with only a few fields

complex_single_country.description: A `complex` Angola document with many fields of different types

name_document.description: A super simple document with one field name

delete.description: Delete an individual document based on the document `_id`.

post.description:
Store a document into elasticsearch, the `_id` for the record will be 
generated by elasticsearch. 

If the index to store the document does not already exist it will be created 
with the default settings and mappings. 

The HTTP response code is 201 for this request.

simple_single_country1.description: A **simple** Afghanistan document with only a few fields

simple_single_country2.description: A **simple** √Öland Islands document with only a few fields

simple_single_country3.description: A **simple** American Samoa document with only a few fields

complex_single_country.description: A `complex` Angola document with many fields of different types

name_document.description: A super simple document with one field name

post.description:
This is the most feature rich endpoint in elasticsearch - coming from sql the searches that you can
perform will **blown your mind**. 

We will just cover the basics here now - but lots more to come on this. 
A number of example query types have been provided. 

This end point can also been used to sample some documents when submitted without a request body 
(i.e. with no search parameters). By default only ten documents will be returned. 

The sample response shows illustrates the structure that will be returned. 
At the top level we have details about the search execution (e.g. `took`, `timed_out` and shard details)
Then we have a `hits` key which has summary details on the search (e.g. `max_score` and `total` hits)
as well as sub `hits` key which lists the search results in score order.

range_query.description: Basically return all country documents with an area of greater than or equal to `1`

multi_field_name_query.description: A boolean query across the `name` field indexed by three different analyzers. The higher quality analyzers are boosted. This query also demostrates named queries. Allowing you to see which sub queries hit the underlying document.

post.description:
Delete all documents that match a query. All of the powerful search language can be used here
to identify what needs to be deleted. Depdending on the number of documents to be deleted you 
may choose to submit this request synchronously or asynchronously based on the `wait_for_completion`
flag. 

If you choose asynchronously you are provided a `task_id` that you can use to manage the request
at a later point.

range_query.description: Basically return all country documents with an area of greater than or equal to `1`

post.description:
The *analyse* endpoint allows you test out how your data will be analysed and indexed. The default behaviour is for your search terms to be indexed using the same analysis chain. E.g. if you split terms on dashes and lowercase the characters the same processing will be applied at index time to the documents as well as at search time to the searched terms. Out of the box elastic comes with 8 "built-in" analyzers, which are a pre configured combination of: - Character Filters, - Tokenizers, and - Token Filters Popular analyzers include: - Standard - which tokenizes based on unicode text logic, removes punctuation and lowercases terms. - Keyword - which basically preforms no analysis, including no tokenization (e.g. a phase comes in and comes out a phase). - Simple - which tokenizes whenever it hits a character that is not a letter. - Stop - which removes stop words (based off the simple analyzer). If the out of the box analysers don't meet your requirements, you can create your own analysis chain. Which basically just involves stringing together the avaliable Character Filters, Tokenizers and Token Filters. Examples of each are provided below:
Character Filters - preprocess characters before passed to tokenizer Character filters include: - **Mapping** - maps text (e.g. `:)` = good/happy). - **HTML Strip** - basically tries to remove HTML garbage from text before indexing. - **Pattern Replace** - firstly I've never had a need to use this character filter. It allows you to use regex to fiddle with the text.

Tokenization - how the text is broken down into tokens Avaliable tokenizers include: - **Letter** (breaks on non leters) - **Standard** (grammer based tokenisation) - note however the apostrophe `s` is kept with the preceding word - **Classic** (pretty good for english however `standard` is preferred now with most general language support) - **Ngram** (ngrams for all tokens) - default is min_gram 1 and max_gram 2 - **Edge_ngram** (ngrams from the edges) - default is min_gram 1 and max_gram 2 - **Keyword** (no tokenization)

Token Filters - processing of tokens (add, modify, delete) from tokenizer Avaliable Token Filters include: - **Apostrophe** - removes apostrophe and text following the apostrophe (e.g. john's becomes john) - **Stopwords** - removes configured stopwords so they are not indexed. - **stemmer** - which supports a number of stemming algorithms. - **Snowball** - snowball stemming of terms.

Including `"explain" : true` in the request will allow you to review the full analysis chain.

Standard_Analyzer.description: Standard analyzer, note the lowercasing and removal of non leters an numbers.

Keyword_Analyzer.description: Basically no analysis, no lowercasing, no tokenization, no removing punctuation - (just phrase in phrase out).

Stop_Analyzer.description: Stop analyzer example. Note the removal of the term `The`.

Mapping_Character_Filter.description: Map one or multiple characters to different text. In this example we are mapping emojis.

HTML_Strip_Character_Filter.description: Remove HTML from text. Really helpful if you are scrapping and indexing the extracted html. You can see in the example that all the HTML tags are removed.

Pattern_Replace_Character_Filter.description: Identify text to be replaced with a regex pattern. The example takes an account number string and creates a number from all the numbers contained in the string.

Standard_Tokenizing.description: Grammer based tokenisation - note however the apostrophe `s` is kept with the preceding word in the example. This is the default configured tokenizer - really good value - you can get a long way with this tokenizerNote in the example we have also provided a lowercase filter to the analysis chain.

Simple_Tokenizing.description:
If you don't want to use one of the default tokenisers you can make your own. Here we specify a few different tokenize on characters. 
 
The example is intended to highlight this is actually harder than you think and users never type in what you expect.

Classic_Tokenizier.description:
Pretty good for english toeknization however `standard` is preferred now with more general language support). 
Each tokenizer comes with some configuration parameters. For example `max token length` for the classic tokenizer.

Ngram_Tokenizier.description:
Standard Ngram tokenization of each word. Noting for ngram matching you probably need to use a diffrent search time analyzer. 
Cause the default behaviour will be to tokenize the search term through this analysis chain.

Edge_Ngram_Tokenizier.description:
Standard Edge Ngram tokenization of each word. Noting for ngram matching you probably need to use a diffrent search time analyzer. 
Cause the default behaviour will be to tokenize the search term through this analysis chain.

Keyword_Tokenizier.description: Keyword tokenizing is basically no tokenisation. However you may wish to pairkeyword tokenisation with a lower case filter, so whey you perform a term aggregation on the textvalues with mixed case will be merged together. Of note in the example is that the analyze endpoint does support a list of terms to analyze.

Simple_Pattern_Tokenizier.description: Tokenizing based on supplied simple patten. In this example we have some medicine and we want to strip the volumes out of the names

Character_Group_Tokenizer.description: Super simple example of CSV tokenizing using the character group tokenizer

value.text: to be or not to be, that is the question

Stemming_Snowball_Filter.description: Stemming of tokens using the snowball algorithm

Stemming_Kstem_Filter.description: Stemming of tokens using the Kstem algorithm. Equivalent to the `light_english` stemmer. . Most of these stemming algorithms assume that the text has already been lower cased. Hence why we have the lowercasign filter as the first filter.

Stemming_English_Filter.description: Standard english stemming. Noting the additional filters applied.
